messages: eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3 (00:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, since pushState doesn't cause a history traversal, there's no language saying that the UA should save the scroll position of the previous history entry.

eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3 (00:03): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, well...inasmuch as the UA can do whatever it wants with the scroll position, it's not a problem.  But maybe it should be there, since it merits being mentioned in the history traversal algorithm.
eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3 (00:04): At least, I forgot to do it when I implemented pushState.  :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:04): i mean, should the state be saved?
eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3 (00:04): Say you scroll down, pushState, scroll around, and then go back.  Shouldn't you get the old scroll position back?
eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3 (00:05): Well, it's still broken even if you don't think so:
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:05): most apps i can imagine using pushState() would either not have any scroll position or would change the page so much on popstate that it'd be academic

eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3 (00:06): Suppose you scroll down, pushState, then go visit some other page entirely.  Then you go back to the first history entry.  We should restore your scroll position, but we never saved it!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:07): can you file a bug or send mail?
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (00:22): hsivonen, createContextualFragment is something we copied from Gecko
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (00:22): hsivonen, we did not want to have it
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (00:22): hsivonen, so if Gecko changes it we can change it too
fd9ef1223e855714294498ebfde79f98 (00:26): i think it's jsut partofhtml5.com
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (00:28): I wish it was not there :)
a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee (00:28): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Isn't Base64 limited to ASCII?
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (00:28): 8b7a8196348038c107614af0b08f2d21, I kind of like this new entity thing now, btw
8b7a8196348038c107614af0b08f2d21 (00:29): a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee: the output is binary.  we're going to need to translate it to characters
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (00:31): a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee, per the PHP manual it should work fine for arbitrary octets
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (00:32): in fact "This encoding is designed to make binary data survive transport through transport layers that are not 8-bit clean, such as mail bodies."
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:32): base64 encoding is binary -> text, decoding is text -> binary
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:33): we just have to define the encoding
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (00:33): yeah, utf-8, anything else is not really acceptable
a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee (00:34): so you can encode anything with base64?
9dfea2f9bd9114520591dceb20d528a1 (00:34): As long as you don't mind the size increase :)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:35): a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee: that's a base64 encoded PNG
a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee (00:35): I don't know where my head was at
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:35): probably left it with your sense of logic, by the door!
a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee (00:35): (somewhere where base64 is also smaller than its source)
a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee (00:36): ah, see, I listen to the rules :)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:36): Wow, your life must be dull.
9dfea2f9bd9114520591dceb20d528a1 (00:38): Only boring people need to break the rules to have fun
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:39): I just break the rules to escape the norm and make people feel uneasy
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:40): Being like everyone else is boring.
a1fbe72f47651e50181e743dc550aeee (00:40): the rules were made for a reason
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:43): tries to think of a rule a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 has broken
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:43): Maybe "don't lie" is a rule
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:43): But he is lying aout breaking rules
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:44): He is a paradoxical rule breaker!
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:44): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I thought I'd at least broken your rules. E.g., no metal.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (00:45): No that is just violting the boundaries of good taste
b45082526d2f65fa02eee54f1a7995fc (00:55): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: should a media element delay the load event when it is not in a document?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:55): eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3: btw re http://people.mozilla.org/ eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3/respkg/ you can use "the document's address", pushState() doesn't change that (it changes "the document's current address")
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:56): b45082526d2f65fa02eee54f1a7995fc: i think this makes sense; in particular, images do the same thing iirc
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:56): and audio is useful even when not in the doc
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:57): eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3: any news on that btw? i'm just looking at it now, would love to hear any experience you've had with it.

eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3 (00:58): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, well, I'm waiting on someone here to do the incremental zip extraction part.  I've been hearing it's coming Real Soon Now for a bit longer than I'd like.

eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3 (00:58): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, :)  My rough, unscientific tests gave pretty positive results.  But what I'm really interested is seeing whether people can get a speedup on their real pages.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:59): makes a refreshing change to see someone be as detailed! :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:00): eab22ddafe9ed99f3735e412bf7ae3e3: heh, you used the html5 "library" :-)

88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (01:01): dbaron posted substantive feedback to public-html.  Will you catch that, 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, or do we need to tell people not to use public-html for that?
